titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M110 [The Reader: Spenser with his eye upon the reader in the great room.]. Typescript fragment, with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned and undated. 5p.
Paginated 26-30. On verso of p. 29, a fragment from Between the Acts, paginated 186.

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

div.p: with his eye upon the reader in the great room. Yet the audience for all its size and compulsion is silent.

p.sup: If we cd. (could) measure the effect of the audience we shd. (should) have a hold upon the play.

div.p:
That is one of the deep gulfs that lies between us and the play. They crowd there; daily; but they neither
priase (praise) nor blame. We must compare it with our won (own) sielnce (silence) at the or the A new art comes upon us so surpinsgly (surprisingly) that we sit silent, recognising what we cannot measure. To the Elizabethans the expressive power of words after their long inadequacy ust (must) have been overwhelming. There at the or at the men and women whose only reading had been the Bible or some old chonicle (chronicle) came out into the light of the present moment. They saw themselves splendidly dressed. They heard themslves (themselves) saying out loud what they had never said yet. They heard their aspirations, their profanities, their ribaldires (ribaldries) spoken out loud by human voices in poetry.

The play then owes its hyperbole to the audience in the penny seats. At their command it is vio;ent (violent); it xmxmxmmxmx it is coarse; it is poexxx xmxmxmxm a parody, of actual facts. like our own detective stories and best sellers a paody (parody) a trasnformation (transformation) of actual fact. But in the seats in the covered part of the house, there were nobles, rulers, scholars. Their silenc (silence) is harder to explain. For they were
redares (readers); they had the Latins and the Greeks at the back of their minds. How could it have been that the trained taste of such speactoars (spectators) received the extraordinary illumination of these English plays with no more comment

p.sup: said nothing about the [revelation?], was not outraged, by an excited - as seems to be the common reader to a [illeg.]

div.p: How can it have been that they made no critical comment upon this extraordinary xmxmxmxmxmxmmxx revelation of this new art?

Perhaps in his essays supplies a reason. "These things be but toyes" he wrote in the essay called To the aristocratic sch lar (scholar) the players were still only mo ntebanks (mountebanks) bear leaders and acrobats. They spoke in the vulgar tongue. Off the stage they lived in the heart of darkness. lying on the bed in Deptford reached out and stabbed in the head whoever in the back. Mr Ingram gave Marlowe a mortal wound then drove his dagger through Marloews (Marlowe's) eeeye (eye) over his right eye. S through the body with a sword that cost three and sixpence. So complete was bacons contempt for this underworld that he could be tolerant. The stage is more beholding to Love than the Life of Man..... great spirits and great businesses do keep out of thid ([this? their?]) weak passion." The proper place for the wak weak passion was the stage, for love leads to speaking in perpetual hyperbole.

The proper tipic (topic) of discussion in the upp r (upper) world was the life of man. The tiles (titles)of the Essays enurmate (enumerate) enurmarte (enumerate) those topics. "Of Truth. Of Death. Of Unity in Religion. Of Revenge. Of Simulation and Dissimulation. Those were the subjactes (subjects) that the rulers discussed at their high tables. The sediment of that conversation is in the rich deposits of the essays. He is concerned with the great world of action; with government; with the tortuous

nature of Princes; with the arts by which rulers can sway, can coax, and can supress. He lives netirely (entirely) in the world of great spirits and great business. The common people is contemptible. "The master of superstition is the Peopoe (People). Praise "if it be from the common people, it is commnoly (commonly)
false and naught. The lowest virtues draw priase (praise) from them; the middle virtues work in them Astonihsment (Astonishment); and admiration; but of the highest vertues they have no sense or perceibging (perceiving) at all..."

The soul that walked between delicate groves keeps to a narrow path between hedges. While ranged the world.
micing (mixing) garrulously with everyone, and speculating freely, kept to the narrow path. Yet even in the shade his thought is embodied. His deep meditations are given visibe (visible) xxxxx concrete form. "Nay bretire (retire) men cannot when they would:
neither will they when it were reason; bu (but) are impateint (impatient) of privateness even in age and sickness which require the Shadow; Like old Townsmen that will still be sitting at ther (their) street door, though thereby they offer Age to scorn."
Even in the delicate grove thought is coloured.

p.sup: The colours that show shew best by candlelight, are: white, carnation, & a kinde of sea-water green

div.p:
His contempt was fr (for) hyperbole; not for the art of speech. He was teaching the ranting players to speak slowly, closely subtly. He was proving that there is another kind of poetry,
thepoetry (the poetry) of prose. He was doing his part to bring the critic (critical) share in bringing the shade faculty into being. prose of the mind He was making an end of anonymity. There by [making?]
xxx 29

Anonymity was a great possession. It gave the early writing a general nature. It gave us the ballds (ballads); it gave us the songs. It allowed us to know nothing of the mans name. had great privileges. He is not resopnsible. He is not self conscious. He can borrow. He can repeat. He can say what very (every) one feels. No one asks that he shall stamp his own name on his work. He keeps at a distance from the present moment. Anon the lyric poet repeats over and over again that flowers fade; that death is the ned (end). He is never tired of celebrating red roses and white breasts. The anonymous playwright has like the singer this nameless vitality, somwthing (something) drawn from the crowd in the penny seats and not yey (yet) dead in ourselves. For we too become anonymous nand (and) forget something that we have learnt in reading the p;ays (plays) that no one has troub led (troubled) to set a name to.

But at some point there comes a break when anonymity withdraws. It comes presumably when the playwrgight (playwright) has
abosrbed (absorbed) the contrbution (contribution) of the audience; and returns it to them in a single figure which is individual. There is a moment in play aft (after) play when the audience is no longer master of the playwright; yet is not separate from him. A common life still unites them, but the playwright becomes increasingly diminant. This separation comes fitfully. Now we say He is speaking our woxmxmxx thoughts.
NoO (O) God, O God that it were possible To undo thin s (things) done; to call back yesterday.
"But we neednt have been to all that trouble," she continued "making the Barn ready, for it didnt rain this year"
"This year, last year, next year, never..." muttered old . "Tinker, tailor, soldier, sailor..." He was talking in his sleep.

Lucy slipped her letter into its envelope. It was time to read her book---the . She had lost her place. She looked at the pictures; mammoths and mastodons, and prehistoric birds. Then she found the page where she had stopped.

The darkness had incrased (increased), and it was cold. With a little shiver, Mrs Swithin drew her sequin shalw (shawl) about hew shoulders She was too deep in the story to ask for the window to be shut. "London" said the author " a s (was) then a swamp...
Thick groves of trees covered the land, and on the top oftheir matted branches, birds sang..."

The great square of the window showed only sky now. It was a losing its light; it was svere severe and stone xxxxx blue. The shadow crept over Bartholomews face. He looked leafless, spectral. As a dog shudders its skin, his skin shuddered. He rose, shook himself, glared at nothing, and stalked from the room. They hard the paws padding on the carpet behind him.

Lucy turned the page quickly, guiltily, like a child who will be told to go to bed before it raches (reaches) the end of the chapter. Pre-historic man, she read, half human, half monster, rose from his semi-crouching position

Now we note the beauty of the words. But often it is a suspended, derelict beauty. Chaos inter (intervenes)
venes (intervenes). The rl ation (relation) of part to part is outraged. The balance is imperfect. Here is profusion; there bareness. The anony ous (anonymous) playwright is irresponsible. He cares nothing has no conscieince about truth; he cares only for the plot. We are left in the end without an end. The emotion is e wasted.

But graudally (gradually) the mist withdraws. So many playwrgihts (playwrights) are explroing (exploring) So many private people are pressing up their weight of unepxpressed (unexpressed) emotion upon the writers
conscious ess (consciousness). Country squires are finding themsleves (themselves) able to say what they think without quoting . The curatin (curtain) rises incesaantly (incessantly) upon play after play. Every Each time, with [illeg.] it rises upon a more complex, highly matured drama. After it has risen again and again it rises finally upon upon the completely embodied; and upon the completely controlled. It rises upon and and and . Finally it rises upon . But the play has outgrown the uncovered theatre where the sun beats and the rain pours. The theatre must be replaced by the theatre of the brain. is replaced by the man who writes a book. The audience is replaced by the the reader. Anon, when is dead.
